Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Technical Framework for Testing, Simulating, and Designing Stable Assets
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is enhanced ability to design stable assets and currencies, particularly in the cryptocurrency `stablecoin' space. This project develops testing and design technology that allows a scientific approach to designing new stablecoins and provides tools for agents in decentralized finance to make informed decisions about risk and investment. Both serve to enhance the long-term stability of stablecoins, which could form the basis for a robust decentralized financial system and facilitate economic adoption of cryptocurrencies. The testing and design technology can be used by stablecoin companies and investors in these markets (such as hedge funds). For the former, the technology is useful to perform validation and to make informed design choices. In the latter, the technology can be used to provide trading and value indicators and to measure the risks in different positions.

This I-Corps project develops a framework for understanding stable assets that provides the testing, simulation, and design capabilities missing in the decentralized finance space. This requires new financial models involving various algorithmic contracts between anonymous agents in a multi-period system that requires recurring actions without a central bank. Aside from these models, which explain actual stablecoin movements, no existing models apply to this setting. This framework involves substantial market design based on these models. Market design is a new field at the intersection of economics and computer science; it studies how markets can be designed to work well. The complexity of stablecoin protocols presents a substantial computer science component to the research. The models enable market simulation and understanding of market dynamics arising from different protocol design, which allows improved learning in how to design better stablecoins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A non-custodial stablecoin is a digital coin residing entirely on a blockchain that aims to maintain a stable value. In particular, it is non-custodial because there is no bank or custodial entity holding reserve funds or exchanging assets. Instead, the stablecoin involves a complicated on-chain risk transfer system that takes advantage of the ability to escrow collateral algorithmically through smart contracts (i.e., computer programs that run on a blockchain) without relying on trusted third parties. In addition to being non-custodial, the smart contracts (i.e., computer programs) are potentially openly accessible for anyone to interact with, regardless of nationality or socioeconomic status, and openly auditable so that anyone can verify their health and operation. A successful stablecoin would bootstrap price stability into the growing space of decentralized finance, which, in an optimistic view, promises to deliver complex financial functionality with the same non-custodial benefits.

We developed a framework for testing, simulating, and designing stablecoin protocols that incorporates models and results that we developed in academic work. We also explored stablecoin designs that are more resilient in the face of our results. We started the NSF I-Corps program by exploring how our framework of models could be applied by cryptocurrency investors and protocol designers to test new designs. We explored who first adopters of these protocols are and their value propositions. These primarily include under-banked individuals and organizations, including crypto-native businesses (e.g., decentralized communities that run other blockchain protocols) for treasury management, for which they require stable and liquid blockchain assets with low counterparty risks, and households in unstable markets, where stablecoins are stable savings alternatives and provide means for low-fee cross-border remittance transactions. These are current needs that are quickly growing and that, for the most part, require the unique non-custodial technology we are researching as they are largely under-served by traditional financial systems.
